text:
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW.

PRINCE ALBERT, SASK., FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1884.

BANKING HOUSE
of Macarthur & Knowles,
Prince Albert, N.W.T.

AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the Local Agricultural Society will be held at the office of Mr. Smith, Baker, Prince Albert, on Wednesday, the 1st inst.

Wednesday and Thursday, The 3rd and 4th of October, will be the dates for the annual fair, which will be held at the grounds of Mr. Smith, Baker, Prince Albert.

The fair will be open from 9 A.M. until 5 P.M., and will feature exhibits of livestock, vegetables, and other agricultural products.

THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW

SPINK & MAVEETY

T. G. JACKSON'S LETTER.

Our attention has been directed to a letter in the weekly Globe issue of the 11th inst., dated from Prince Albert, on the 16th, and signed by T. G. Jackson, whose efforts have been so manifestly aimed at the suppression of opinions intended as an expression of the writer's feelings angry towards our editor. Discarding as we do the unprofitable attempt that he before composing his epistle the writer had been more than a Tea getting Jackson, we can only say that when an old gentleman, who has been detected publicly declaring himself an unrestrained lover of nothing exhibiting any more strongly marked characteristic than that of an amiable stupidity, suddenly takes a fresh departure and rushing into print sets up as a full blown opponent of all calls of duty from him by such name naughty names as liar, his mental condition is clearly such as to afford ground for the gravest apprehensions as to his friendly attitude towards the best interests of the community, but we are well aware that the truth utterances of superannuated cranks and loud-mouthed ranters run the risk of sympathy from those who lack the power to help us, and who are doing so fast as can be expected under the circumstances. A few such letters as this of Mr. Jackson's would serve to bring Mr. Rich into possible further discredit than anything we can write.

THE EXHIBITION.

In our columns we have noticed the advertisements of an agricultural show to be held next month by the Local Agricultural Society in this town. This show will have one peculiarity which is not common with such shows as it will be the first of its kind ever held in this district, and we earnestly call upon the members of the community that it deserves to be held for the purpose of affording a beginning, in some respects, the annual weather during the spring and summer season at the exhibition of such splendid specimens of the productions of the soil as we can generally produce hereabouts, also showing means the best the country can do the samples will compare favorably with any in regions less generally favored. As a result of a postal ballot petition the arrangements have been entrusted to able and experienced men who have included in the prize list everything for competition which serves to be indicative of the prosperity of the agricultural development of the country. It is peculiarly necessary in the present condition of the country that the improvement of stock, both sheep and cattle, should be a subject of much attention, and the introduction of improvements beyond the power of any but a few individual efforts, and we trust that this society will make every reasonable effort possible to bring forward the best specimens of both from every part of the district, but will soon be in a position to claim substantial and from the Government.

The Prince Albert Times, a weekly paper, will be published every Thursday at Prince Albert, N.W.T. The Times will be edited by Mr. J. W. Jackson, and will contain news, views, and opinions on various subjects. The Times will also publish advertisements and classifieds. The Times will be delivered to subscribers at $2 per year.
Lorne Agricultural Society

District of Saskatchewan

Patrons:
Hon. L. Clarke, and F. Swanson, Esq., members of the society.

Officers of the Society:
Augustus Cooper, President.
Andrew Spencer, Jr., Vice-President.
William Miller, Jr., 2nd Vice-President.
Charles Adams, Secretary-Treasurer.
Thomas Scott, Auditor.
William Macdonald, Auditor.

The board is composed of twenty-six directors.

Rules and regulations:

1. Any person desiring to correspond with the Secretary-Treasurer will address their communications to Charles Adams, Prince Albert.

2. Entries must be in the hands of the Sec. Treas., not later than Oct. 25th.

3. Fifty cents entry fee must accompany each entry paper for stock, and twenty-five cents for each article.

4. Entries must be made on written forms.

5. Any one may enter who will be allowed an exhibition in any section of any class other than live stock. No animal or article will be allowed to compete in more than two classes, unless the kinds of cattle which are shown separately, and with young and foals, which may be shown separately with their dams.

6. On the receipt of entries each card will be prepared for each animal or article, specifying the class, division, and number of entry, which card must remain attached to the animal or its pen or stall at all times during the course of the period of the exhibition. When postal facilities permit, these cards will be mailed to interested exhibitors. Those who do not receive them may call upon the Sec. Treas.'s office in Prince Albert up to the day of opening.

7. The grounds and buildings will be opened on Thursday the 25th of October. All exhibits, other than live stock, etc., must be brought to the grounds by 12 o'clock noon on Wednesday, Oct. 24th. Live stock must be on the ground and in pens by 8 o'clock a.m. on Tuesday, Oct. 25th. No animals or articles which are live stock shall be removed from the grounds until 6 p.m., Friday, Oct. 26th.

The grounds will be closed at 6 p.m., Oct. 26th, to facilitate the removal of exhibits. Exhibitors living in distant parts will be informed of prices awarded them.

8. No exhibitors, or racks, or other conveyances containing them, will be admitted without a ticket, excepting those who have paid the entrance fee.

9. Articles on exhibition cannot be handled except by the officers of the department to which they belong.

10. Each exhibitor on being admitted with his entry tickets, will be given an admission ticket. The entry tickets on each animal or article will be signed by persons taking them to the grounds for examination, along with the animals or articles, without the use of any other tickets.

11. Necessary attendants upon stock, and animals requiring accommodation, to be furnished with proper accommodations, for each day of the exhibition, with their names written upon them; such tickets will be issued only to persons who bring their teams at the gate only. The Sec. Treas. will be the person to whom to apply for such tickets, which, however, he must furnish by the close of the exhibition.

12. Complementary tickets of admission or badges will be issued to the judges, secretaries, and others required to be present during the exhibition. Any one not having received their tickets prior to the opening of the exhibition, will be refused admittance at the Sec. Treas. on the exhibition grounds.

13. The price of admission will be twenty-five cents each during the show, and no tickets will be issued unless the money is paid. No tickets will be issued unless the money is paid.

14. In all classes of blood horses and pure bred cattle, full pedigrees, properly certified, must accompany the entry. No animals or articles will be accepted as pure breed unless they possess regular stud book pedigree or certificates of registration, and are correctly descended from such stock.

15. Live stock must be in the hands of property of the exhibitor.

16. The age of any animal shall be reckoned from the first day of January in the year of birth.

17. No exhibit shall be awarded a prize unless it has been examined by a select committee of the society, or other qualified persons, and certified by him as being free from disease.

18. Blood must be with the feet at least, or must give evidence of sickness, and must be found during the current year.

19. Bulls must have a ring in their noses or otherwise properly secured to the administration of the live stock superintendent.

20. Grain, roots, seeds, dairy produce, and all other agricultural produce, will be judged by the Agricultural Committee.

21. The prizes will be awarded by the Executive personnel of the exhibition, and will consist of a card informing them of the fact of the award.

22. In the absence of a question in any section, or if the stock or articles exhibited be of inferior quality, the Executive personnel will decide the matter, and will make their decision final.

23. No person will be allowed to interfere with the judges while on the discharge of their duties. Any such interference will forfeit their right to competition, and the prizes which they may have won.

24. Money prizes will be paid by cheque, which will be sent by mail to the winners from the date of the exhibition.

25. Prizes will be awarded to the best of the entire class, and will be charged from that given on the entry tickets, and will be paid by the Sec. Treas.

26. No exhibitor, or rack, or other conveyance, may be withdrawn by withdrawing prizes, except from the grounds, or under instructions as the Executive may direct.

27. The management will take every possible precaution under the circumstances, to prevent the loss of property belonging to the exhibitors, and will not be responsible for the loss of any article, excepting the animals or articles which are live stock, and any property which, although in the charge of the officers, shall be liable to be removed by the officers or committees according to circumstances.

How to Make Candy:

This book gives full directions for making all kinds of plain and fancy candy. The recipes for making caramel, butterscotch, sugar, and all the other kinds of candies contained in this book are the same as used by the leading candy manufacturers, and will make them caramel at home, at least ten cents per pound extra.

EAST END NOTICE.

I hereby inform you that all my accounts are now closed, and all parties interested in my business are requested to settle the same immediately, if not costs will be added.

N.B.—On and after this date I will keep no book accounts. Terms strictly cash.

WM. GORDON

April 1st, 1884.
CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporters.

For green apples go to T. O. Davis, See T. O. Davis' new advertisement on this page.

A party arrived yesterday for the Rev. Mr. McMillan.

November 6th has been appointed a Thanksgiving Day.

This fall, the trees begin to feel it approaching winter.

Mr. Tom Taylor and family have gone on a visit to Duck Lake.

Mr. A. J. Davis, who only day arrived back from Butteville last week.

A train of carts arrive at goods for T. O. Davis yesterday morning.

Mr. Wm. Brown left here Tuesday with six passengers for Toronto.

Business is a little dull in town just now, the farmers being all busy at their harvest.

Mr. J. L. Johnson returned from his trip to the East, by mail on Monday evening.

Mr. Jac. Macintosh, accompanied by Mr. J. L. Davis, left for Saskatoon on Monday last.

Sportsmen ought to have a thrilling experience, but the prairie sodden is unusually so plentiful as they might be.

Mrs. Swanson, with some lady friends, has gone across the river to gather berries which we hear are very plentiful there.

The Sunday School, the first organiza-

tion of the Western Industrial Soci-

ety, was formally opened by His Hon-

our the Lieutenant Governor of Ontario.

On Saturday evening Mr. and Mrs. R. B. Way returned from their trip with her two children, and we are pleased to learn that the visit to the East has proved of much benefit to them both.

Mr. Thos. Stanhope accompanied by Messrs. Barker and Pratt, have gone out on a hunting excursion, and we pre-

sume from their letters that they must expect to stay away some time and to bring back a lot of game.

As will be seen by the advertisement to this issue, the Winnipeg weekly Free Press offers special inducements to sub-

scribers to keep up their subscription.

Every reader is asked to show appear-

ance, and the liberal offer of the publishers will no doubt be fully appreciated by the satisfied old Free Press readers.

Our town is to build up to the propor-

tions which it is to be urged in some cir-

cumstances, must be directed in all directions by those who direct it.

It is always remembered that every effort made by the town council to beautify and make attractive this town is not going far to make the town attractive to set-

tlers, as a great deal is to be done there.

In the meantime, however, while it must be remembered that only the election of the ablest men to overlook the operations of the town council can be met by promptly paid up taxes can ensure success, and that every citizen interested in the welfare of the town is most profitably invested.

The money in a house should be saved before it is spent, and the citizens should be taught to save money, and not to waste it.

It may be remembered that we have more than once expressed the hope that by the erection of parks and buildings of some kind, the citizens would be able to meet the wants of the community in a manner that would be most profitable.

The money in a house should be saved before it is spent, and the citizens should be taught to save money, and not to waste it.

In anticipation of the tax which has been promised us by the enterprising citizens, Mr. Thomas Stanhope has built a house for being the first to put a practical example to our settlers in this direction.

Now, as we have said before, in the case, that tax would prove a good tax, and we fail to see how our motorists can re-

tain their benefits to themselves and the public by buying a tax which cannot be imported, which they can buy and sell at far greater reasonable prices.

The ad-

vantages to the town would be immense, if circulation here is strong, and Mr. Stanhope, who only came back names to work, will be able to make a good crop of all that goes to form the produce of pigs will enable farmers here and elsewhere to charge a higher price for them, but when the market is thus, that, in fact, pigs so cheaply as to defy outside competition.

LOST IN THE BUSH.

Billie Shingles' Troubles.

As our reporter was taking a stroll on Monday evening, he noticed a gentleman walking along the road toward the town.

He called him to himself. On a nearer approach, he found it was Billie Shingles.
